name: betula-grossa
wildlife-value: This plant supports the larvae of Eastern Tiger Swallowtail (Papilo glaucus). They have three flights from February-November in the deep south and March-September in the north.   The adult Eastern Tiger Swallowtail butterflies feed on milkweed, joe pye weed, wild cherry, and lilac.
particularly-resistant-to-insects/diseas: Bronze birch borer that attacks many of the white-barked species.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Female flowers give way to nut-like fruit containing winged seeds that disperse with the wind.
flower-description: Monoecious catkin flowers appear early to mid-spring and are pollinated by wind.  Male flowers are yellow; female are insignificant.
leaf-description: Dark green leaves, 2 to 4 inches long and 1 to 2 inches wide. Bright yellow fall color.
bark-description: Young bark is smooth and white and resembles cherry bark  with horizontal stripes becomingÂ dark gray to brown or pink with age and exfoliating with thin papery curls.  Bark on mature trees gets vertical fissures. Bark is aromatic  with a scent of wintergreen.
stem-description: Aromatic (wintergreen) young stems are yellow-brown aging to gray.
